question: I don't know why you're so weirded out, this is not San Quentin, it's just a nuthouse. Most of these people don't even know where they are, they're not gonna hurt you.
answer: In a few minutes we're gonna be in a room with a killer. That doesn't bother you?

question: Hey, you're the one that wanted to major in journalism. Anyhow, wasn't the guy something like twelve or thirteen when he did it, it was twenty-five years ago, he probably doesn't even remember it.
answer: Do you smell shit?

question: Oh yeah, from the college?
answer: Yes sir.

question: My name's Jerry Woolridge.
answer: Nice to meet you. I'm Marsha Dwiggins and this is Theresa Evans. She's here to take the pictures.

question: Y'all have a seat. Is this all of you?
answer: Yes sir.

question: I think there must have been a little mix up. I told your sponsor or teacher or whatever he is, there couldn't be any pictures. It's s'posed to be just a little story or article or something, isn't that right?
answer: Well, yeah, it's for the school newspaper. But it has pictures. I mean it's a regular paper, you know.

question: Karl's real sensitive about having his picture made. He wouldn't even be on the bulletin board for the Easter Collage. Melvin, would you get me a good hot cup with two sugar substitutes? You girls want some coffee?
answer: No thank you.

question: Well, what do we do? We drove all the way out here.
answer: Let's just go, Marsha.

question: No, we have to get this story.
answer: I thought you'd be happy to leave.

question: I don't think he's talked to a woman in twenty-five or so years. That I know of anyway. That's why I said to send a man. At least maybe he'd answer a question or two for a man. I'm all for helping the college out, believe me. It might be a real good article or story.
answer: Can't you talk to him? Maybe talk him into it. I'm a real good interviewer. Just get me in the room with him.

question: Melvin, go get Karl and take him down to the old classroom. I'll talk to him and see what we can do. You see, Karl, growing up, only knew that sex was wrong and that people who did it should be killed for it. He couldn't really read but, well, neither could his mother. But, his father made sure that his mother knew what the Bible said. And she made sure Karl knew. You know he slept in a hole in the ground under a toolshed, right?
answer: I knew he slept in a toolshed.

question: His mother told him that he was their punishment. Hers and his father's; from God, for having sex--
answer: Before they were married?

question: I don't think so. Just period, I think. She told him... God gave them the ugliest creation he could think of. Karl has an entire book -- a notebook. On every page it says "Franklin Chapter 1 Verse number 1." He wrote that a few years ago after he'd learned to write. His father's name was Franklin.
answer: That's really strange. What does it mean?

question: Karl, you know, do you remember when I told you about those people from that newspaper? They want to ask you some questions about your release. They think it would make an interesting story. Will you talk to 'em? Get interviewed. Now, they're women. I think it might be good for you to. You're gonna be seein' all kinds of people when you go on the outside. This'll help you I believe. Well, it surprised the dickens out of me. He said he'll talk to you. But, here's the thing. He'll only talk to you. He doesn't want you to ask him anything. And you shouldn't stare at him.
answer: How am I going to conduct an interview if I can't ask him any questions?

question: It's the best you're gonna get. I'm sorry.
answer: Can I ask you a question? If he's so troubled, why are you letting him out? What if he does it again? It happens all the time.

question: He's free. His time's up. That's the rules. He's been treated and reevaluated. He doesn't show any signs any more.
answer: Signs?

question: Is he leaving right this minute?
answer: We've got some paperwork to take care of. Pretty soon. Don't worry, you won't run into him in the parking lot.

question: I didn't mean that.
answer: I hope the best for you, Miss Dwiggins, with your school and your paper and all.

question: Where will he go?
answer: Wherever he wants to. I think he's going back to Millsburg where he's from. It's just about twenty miles from here.

question: Will he be supervised?
answer: As much as anybody else is, I guess. Y'all have a good rest of the day now.

question: I reckon I'm gonna have to get used to looking at pretty people.
answer: Yes, I guess you are.

question: I reckon I'm gonna have to get used to them lookin' at me, too.
answer: You better go get your things.

question: I ain't got nothing but them books.
answer: You better go get 'em.

question: All right then.
answer: Can I help you?

question: I was kindly wantin' somethin' or 'nother d'eat.
answer: Well, what did you want?

question: You have any biscuits for sale?
answer: Naw, we don't have biscuits. Did you decide, sir?

question: What you got that's good to eat?
answer: Well, I guess it's all good.

question: What do you like to eat here?
answer: French fries. I like to eat them pretty good.

question: French-fried potaters.
answer: Yeah.

question: How much you want fer 'em? I'll get some of them I reckon.
answer: Sixty for small and seventy-five for large.

question: Give me the big'uns.
answer: These dang things are heavy. Hard to carry, too.

question: What you got in there, warshing?
answer: Yeah.

question: Ain't you got no mama and daddy to tend to it?
answer: I got a mama, but she's at work over at Ben's Dollar Store. My daddy's dead. He got hit by a train.

question: How fer you going with them sacks full of warsh?
answer: About a half a mile I think it is.

question: I'll help you tote 'em if I don't give out first.
answer: Okay. You don't have to though. My name is Frank Wheatley. What's your name?

question: Karl's my name.
answer: What's you last name?

question: Childers.
answer: What are all them books?

question: Different ones. One's the Bible. One of 'ems a book on Christmas. One of 'ems how to be a carpenter.
answer: How come you're carryin' them around with you.

question: Ain't got nowhere to set 'em down.
answer: Don't you live somewhere?

question: I did live there in the state hospital.
answer: Why'd you live there?

question: I killed some folks quite awhile back. They said I wadn't right in the head and they put me in there in the nervous hospital instead of puttin' me in jail.
answer: They let you out?

question: Yeah.
answer: How come?

question: They told me I was well. They had to turn me loose.
answer: Are you well?

question: I reckon I feel all right.
answer: You don't seem like you'd kill nobody. This is my house. You can just set those bags on the porch. Do you like to play football?

question: I never was much count at it. I never did get picked out fer it.
answer: Me and the Burnett twins and some boys plays down at the junior high practice field all the time. If you ever want to come by and play. We ain't no good either. Well, I'll see you later.

question: How does a feller go about gettin' up to the state hospital? All right then.
answer: Karl, what in the world are you doing here?

question: I want to come back and stay here.
answer: Well, you can't do that. You're a free man. You've been let out to do as you please.

question: I reckon I don't care nothin' about bein' a free man. I don't know how to go about it.
answer: Well, you have to learn. It'll take some time. Don't you know anybody down there to help you out?

question: Naw.
answer: Your daddy's still livin' down there from what you told me. I guess he wouldn't help you any, would he? I wasn't thinking. You don't know anybody?

question: Naw. Never did know too much of nobody. Not to he'p me out anyway.
answer: Listen, Karl, the truth is I don't know where they expect you to go or what they expect you to do. If it was up to me, I'd let you stay here if that's what you wanted. I'm just doin' my job. You follow me? Listen, I know an old boy that runs a fix-it shop deal down in Millsburg. He used to go to church with me. You're good workin' on small engines and things. If I put my neck out for you with him, will you work at it if he'll hire you?

question: I'm pretty handy I reckon on lawn mowers and whatnot.
answer: I know, I've seen it myself. Would you give that a try?

question: I reckon.
answer: I can't promise he'll hire you. I'll have to tell him about your history.

question: I never was no good with history.
answer: No, I mean your past. About why you were in here. I'll take you first thing in the mornin'. You have anyplace you can stay tonight at all? I just can't let you stay here. It's the rules. If something happened well, I'd be liable.

question: I reckon I can just walk around till the mornin'. Or set and read me a book somewhere.
answer: Karl, would you like a muffin?

question: No thank ye.
answer: I understand Jerry is going to take you somewhere else tomorrow.

question: Sure, honey. You sleep with Mama tonight. I'll sleep with your brother and Karl can take your room. We have company. Now you go on. Well, Karl, there's plenty of blankets and things there. Bathroom's right there in the hall. We'll leave first thing tomorrow.
answer: Jerry, why didn't you give him Bubba's room? Sister's is kind of girly, isn't it?

question: Yeah, I thought about that. No sense in moving him now I guess. Why, hell no, son. What's wrong with you?
answer: 'Isn't' he, Bubba. Don't say ain't.

question: Karl, you up?
answer: Yes sir.

question: Didn't you go to sleep at all, Karl? You been sittin' there like that all night?
answer: Yes sir.

question: Well, I guess we better hit the road.
answer: Hey Jerry, how it's goin'. Good to see you. Been a long time.

question: Good to see you, Bill. How's everybody doin'?
answer: Aw, pretty good. Kids are drivin' me crazy and Phyliss is gonna put me in the poorhouse. Can't complain other than that. Wouldn't do any good if I did. Do you know Scooter, Jerry?

question: No, don't guess I do. Scooter, good to meet you. This is him, the one I talked to you about on the phone. Now like I said, I'll understand if you get nervous about it. I'm not gonna lie to you now, he did get in that trouble but then he was real young.
answer: I remember it real well. Cut them folks to pieces. His mama one of 'em.

question: Oh yeah. Listen I really appreciate it. He needs the job. I don't know what to do with him. He don't have anybody really.
answer: That old man of his still livin' over there on Clark Street I believe.

question: He won't have anything to do with him. Now you say it's all right for him to stay out here in the back?
answer: Fine with me. If he steals anything, I'll take it out of your pocket anyway.

question: He won't steal. I'm tellin' you he's a pretty good ol' boy. Keeps to himself.
answer: Well, I've got a roomful of work for him to do. Can't get Scooter to do any of it.

question: Karl, come over here. I want you to meet your new boss. This is Bill Cox, runs this place. Says you can work here and stay in the back.
answer: Good to know you, Karl.

question: They say you're a whiz on fixin' lawn mowers and things.
answer: I've tinkered around on 'em a little bit.

question: We order from Dairy Queen at noontime usually. We can buy your lunch till you get on your feet a little.
answer: I like them french-fried potaters.

question: Yeah, me too.
answer: They make a good double meat burger.

question: All right then, I'll see y'all later. Karl you done a good day's work. They right about you. Scooter, he's gonna knock you out of a job if you're not careful. I'll see you tomorrow.
answer: Wait up, I'll leave with you and lock up.

question: If it works out and all, maybe we'll get you a key so you can get out at night if you need to. See you later. Scooter, did I tell about the two old boys pissin' off the bridge?
answer: I can't remember.

question: There was these two old boys hung their peckers off of a bridge to piss, one old boy from California and one old boy from Arkansas. Old boy from California says, "Boy this water's cold." Old boy from Arkansas says "Yeah, and it's deep too." Get it? That's a goodun.
answer: Yeah, that's a goodun. I believe you did tell me that one before. I've heard that a bunch. Long time ago.

question: Well, yeah it's a classic. You know, Karl, I got to thinkin' about it last night and it's just not Christian of me to not let you have a key. I mean you been in lockup so long, you don't need me keepin' you locked up. You need to come and go as you please. Here, take this key, it'll get you in and out that back door. Them french fries good?
answer: Yeah, they's good all right.

question: You got any money?
answer: They give me fifty dollars when they turned me loose. I spent up some of it on ridin' the bus and eatin' french-fried potaters.

question: Well, I'm gonna pay you today for this comin' week, so you'll have some walkin' around money. When you get off this evenin' you better go buy some toothpaste and cleanin' up supplies to have back there. Some hard candy and some magazines. Somethin' to keep you busy at night.
answer: All right then.

question: Hey there. I thought I heard somebody on the porch. Wasn't your name Karl?
answer: Yeah it is. Your name's Frank.

question: Yeah. What you doin' by here?
answer: You told me to come by.

question: Did you want to play ball with us?
answer: I ain't no good at it. I just come by.

question: Well, anyhow, I was just fixin' to go see my mama down at Ben's Dollar Store. She's workin' two till eight.
answer: All right then.

question: Wait a minute. You want to go with me? You can meet my mama.
answer: I don't want to worry your mama with company.

question: Aw, come on. You'll like her. She's real nice. She'll give us somethin' if we ask her to. Candy or somethin'.
answer: I was kindly needin' to do some tradin'. Reckon they sell toothpaste?

question: I don't think I've ever seen you before.
answer: Naw, I don't believe you have. I don't reckon I never been in here. This store didn't used to be here.

question: It's been here seventeen years. Did you live here before or something?
answer: I's horned and raised here up till I's twelve year old.

question: What brings you back?
answer: What's that you say?

question: Why are you here now?
answer: They turned me loose from the state hospital.

question: Is that right? Are you going to be staying here long?
answer: I reckon Mr. Woolridge got me hired on to work for Bill Cox's outfit.

question: Do you have family here?
answer: Not really to speak of.

question: Sure, go ahead. Are you sure it's safe to let him around that guy?
answer: Frank's just crazy about him. He likes the way he talks. He helped him carry home the clean laundry.

question: He's been in the state hospital a long time, something must be wrong with him.
answer: He's retarded's all. You know he's always after a father figure and Lord knows Doyle ain't a good one with his mean ass.

question: What about me?
answer: I don't think he sees you as a guy guy.

question: This is what I call my secret place 'cause I come out here when I feel like bein' by myself. I used to come here with Karen Cross. She's kind of like my girlfriend, or used to be. She says she likes Jerry Maroney now. But I'm gonna get her back 'cause I love her. We used to come here and hold hands and talk and read books to each other with a flashlight. She didn't want to have anything to do with me in front of other people 'cause I don't have any money. Well, mama and me, I mean. She seemed to like me a whole lot when we were out here though. She said she loved me, too. Out here. Settin' right on that stump you're on. See, her daddy's a dentist so they're rich. So's Jerry Maroney's daddy. He owns the ice plant. Was your folks well off?
answer: Naw. Didn't have too much. Enough to scrape by on, I reckon.

question: They still around, your folks?
answer: My mother's dead. My daddy's s'posed to be around still. He don't want to have nothin' to do with me though.

question: How do you know?
answer: He never did want to. I figure he ain't changed his mind much.

question: How did your mama die?
answer: You don't need to know all of that. You're just a boy. You need to think about good thoughts while you're still a boy. They'll be plenty of time for the other.

question: I've had a lot of bad thoughts since my daddy died. Sometimes I wish I was still real little and he was still here. My mama's real good, but I wish I had both of 'em. When we went to Memphis one time in the car, it was rainin' so hard we couldn't see the road. But I wadn't scared because I thought as long as daddy was drivin' nothin' could happen to us. I feel that way about mama now. Mama has a boyfriend now. His name is Doyle Hargraves. He works construction so he makes a pretty good livin'. He still don't help mama out with any money though. He ain't no good. He's mean to her. He don't like me at all. Mama says it's because he's jealous I belong to my daddy instead of him. He stays with us all night sometimes, but he's got his own house. Somebody told me it's so he can still have other girlfriends. I like it on the nights when he ain't at our house. I'm not so nervous then.
answer: How come her to keep bein' girlfriends and all with him if he's mean to her?

question: She says it's for the times when he's good to her. She's lonely since daddy died. She said sometimes she don't know why. He threatened to kill her if she ever left him. My daddy would kill him if he was here and somebody was mean to mama. Vaughan, he's real good to mama. Vaughan that you met. But he's not able to do anything to Doyle, he's funny you know. Not funny ha, ha, funny queer. He likes to go with men instead of women. That makes him not to be able to fight too good. He sure is nice though. He's from St. Louis. People who are queer can get along better in a big town. He got transferred here to work. But mama said the real reason he left is 'cause his daddy hated him. For bein' the way he is. I wish he liked to go with women. I'd rather him be mama's boyfriend than Doyle. Karl. You know when I said daddy got hit by a train.
answer: Yeah, I remember you a-tellin' me that.

question: It ain't the truth. He shot hisself with a shotgun on purpose.
answer: Why did he do that, reckon.

question: 'Cause he didn't have enough money to take care of us the way he wanted to. That's what the letter said. He got laid off from work and had to just work odd jobs. I thought he took care of us fine. Karl, did you really kill somebody?
answer: Yeah, I did.

question: Who did you kill?
answer: Two people.

question: Were they bad people?
answer: I thought they was.

question: Maybe they needed it.
answer: I growed up and got taught it ain't right to kill nobody.

question: Now, Karl, you sure you want to go stay with these folks? You're welcome to keep on stayin here. It's workin' out real good.
answer: That boy wants me to.

question: All right then. I'll see you bright and early. How you comin' along on that garden tiller?
answer: I fixed it. Hit's a workin' pretty good.

question: Well, honey, I don't guess I give a shit. I ain't here half the time anyway. If you want a retard livin' in the garage, I don't guess I care. I've got a good tool box and socket set out there I don't want stol'd. I guess I could take it home with me.
answer: He's real honest. He wouldn't steal nothin'.

question: Now son, I wadn't talkin' to you, was I? Was I?
answer: No sir.

question: No sir's right. I'm talkin' to your mama. This is your mama's decision, not yours. I'm lettin' it go on because she asked me, not you. Now is this the kind of retard that drools and rubs shit in his hair and all that, 'cause I have trouble eatin' around that kind of thing. Just like I am about antique furniture and midgets. I can't so much as drink a glass of water around a midget or a piece of antique furniture. Same thing with a droolin' retard.
answer: Doyle, you're awful. You shouldn't be that way.

question: I ain't sayin' it's right. I'm just tellin' the truth. What was he in the nuthouse for?
answer: He's just mentally retarded, I guess.

question: You might want to find out. He might of hacked his family to pieces with a hatchet or somethin'.
answer: Yeah, that's right, Frank, you better ask him. I mean, don't hurt his feelin's or anything, but it would be good to know. I'm sure it's nothin'. He seems real sweet.

question: You sure are hung up on people bein' sweet. Speakin' of which, where's your girlfriend? I thought he was comin' by here for something.
answer: He'll be here in a little while, he's takin' me to get an ice cream.

question: Ain't that the sweetest thing. What am I supposed to do about supper with you traipsin' around with that fag?
answer: You're not crippled. Get in there and make somethin'.

question: Boy, ain't you somethin' else. Talkin' back and everything. It kinda makes me horny when you talk back.
answer: Frank, why don't you go off and play in your room if Doyle's gonna talk nasty.

question: Karl?
answer: Yes sir.

question: So, you're really going to stay here?
answer: That boy wants me to.

question: Did you knock on the door yet?
answer: Naw, I ain't.

question: How long have you been standing here?
answer: Quite a spell, I reckon.

question: Listen, before you get very used to staying here, I think you and I need to talk about a few things. Can I take you to lunch?
answer: I done et just a little bit ago.

question: I mean tomorrow or the next day.
answer: I reckon I can stand to eat a little somethin' or 'nother at noontime tomorrow. Bill Cox generally gets me a box of french fried potaters. But I reckon he can lay off doin' it tomorrow.

question: Goddamnit, I'm talkin' to the man. You set right there, Karl. What's in your bag?
answer: This and that. Toothpaste and whatnot.

question: What's all them books?
answer: Different ones. The Bible's one of 'em.

question: You believe in the Bible?
answer: A good deal of it, I reckon. Can't understand all of it.

question: You're just crazy in a retarded kind of way then. It wouldn't matter to me if you did do violence on somebody 'cause I ain't afraid of shit. You think I'm afraid for you to stay here. You're just a humped over retard it looks like to me. Not really, I'm just jokin' with you. Welcome to our humble home, buddy. Frank needs all the friends he can get. Frank's a real weak little kid. His daddy taught him how to be a pussy.
answer: Stop it, Doyle! Don't talk about daddy, you hear me!

question: Don't talk about daddy. Y'all go on to the garage and let me be.
answer: Come on, Karl.

question: Don't tell your mama we had a little spat. She don't need to be worried with your ass.
answer: I'd like to kill that son of a bitch. I hate him.

question: I'd like to kill that son of a bitch. I hate him.
answer: You ort not to talk that way. You're just a boy.

question: Well, I hate him.
answer: He ort not to talk that away to you neither. He ain't no count. He's mean to you and your mama. Yore mama and that feller that's carryin' me to get somethin' d'eat's gonna be back here directly.

question: Will you stay here with us for a long time?
answer: I reckon if you want me to. I got some of that potted meat and sodie crackers left over if you want some.

question: I don't see how you can eat that stuff with all those insides it's made out of.
answer: I reckon it tastes pretty good to me.

question: I like the way you talk.
answer: I like the way you talk.

question: I like the way you talk.
answer: Okay, Karl, the reason I brought you here was to talk to you about something that is on my mind. I guess I'll put it right out on the table. Where do I start. Linda and Frank are very important to me. They're like family. My own family was never like family. They're horrible people. As a matter of fact I prayed every night for years that my father would die. I finally realized through a lot of therapy that I was wasting my energy on hating him. Now I just don't care. You see, you and I are a lot alike, strange as that may seem. I mean not physically or even mentally really, just well, maybe emotionally or actually the hand we've been dealt in life. We're different. People see us as being different anyway. You're -- well you have your affliction or whatever and I, well mine's not as easy to see. I'm just going to say it. I'm gay. Does that surprise you? That I'm gay. You know what being gay is, don't you?

question: I reckon not.
answer: Homosexual. I like men. Sexually.

question: Not funny, ha, ha, funny queer.
answer: Well that's a very offensive way to put it. You shouldn't say that. You were taught that, weren't you?

question: I've heard it said that way.
answer: Anyway, it's hard to live gay, that's the right way to say it, in a small town like this. I've wanted to leave many times, but my love for Linda and Frank and another certain person that we won't go into have kept me from it. Anyway, I'm rambling. If you're going to live in the Wheatly garage you need to know that it won't be easy. Doyle is a monster. Not just a closed minded redneck, but a monster. A dangerous person. I've told Linda that one day that man is going to really hurt her or that boy. Maybe even kill one of them. I see it in his eyes. I'm very in tune, maybe even psychic. Doyle will make your life hell. You're a perfect target. When I first saw you I was afraid of you. Not really afraid, I guess, just taken aback. But also, I felt a real sensitive feeling from you. And for some reason, Frank has adopted you. Much like a stray animal. I'm sorry, I didn't mean it like that. In a good way. Anyway, I just want you to know what you're in for. I have a good feeling about you. You're good for Frank. Maybe it's that he can have an adult friend on a child's level. I'm sorry, I didn't mean it in a bad way. There's one more thing. It's none of my business why you were in the state hospital. Everyone has something in their past, maybe you tried suicide, maybe you did something -- terrible. But what I see before me is a gentle, simple man. All I want you to promise me is that you're capable of being around Linda and Frank. You know. You would never hurt them under any circumstances, would you?

question: I wouldn't never hurt them.
answer: That's what I thought. I hope I haven't offended you in any way. You seem like a thinker. You seem to always be in deep thought. Tell me something. What are you thinking right now?

question: I was thinkin' I could use me another helpin' of these potaters.
answer: Oh. How about before that?

question: You know what, by God?
answer: What?

question: You know what we ought to do tonight?
answer: Please Doyle, don't.

question: Have a damn party! Call Morris and them and get the band together and just party our asses off. I'd like to show that fuckin' Karl to the guys. They'd get a kick out of that. Don't you know they would.
answer: Please don't. Not tonight. I'm not up for it. They always stay till mornin'. I'm just give out, Doyle.

question: Well, it's on! We're gonna rock. Linda, call Vaughan. Tell him to get over here. I'd like him to be here. I owe him a good time.
answer: No Doyle. Vaughan don't want to come to a party with you.

question: Too late, Honey. Fooled you. Done called him. He'll be here. Or I'll go get him. Come on Karl, I need you to help me ice down a tub of beer, you and Frank. Okay ladies and gentlemen or both. It's come to the time in our show when we like to introduce the band. Over here on lead guitar Mr. Randy Horsefeathers. Come on hit a hot lick, Randy. Well, come on, y'all are supposed to clap now. Come on!
answer: Karl, you better clap your hands or he'll just keep on.

question: But honey, I'll be good. I promise. I love you sweetie. I'm just tryin' to help these two be part of things.
answer: Are you sure you can drive? You've really had a lot of alcohol.

question: Shhhh! This is the national anthem. Not that you afflicted sons of bitches would know anything about it, but this is art. Hey Freddy, what's goin' on boy. I seen your pitcher in the paper for catchin' that big-ass bass. Yeah. We run outta somethin' to drink. Goin' to the county line. You want to race? Catch you later Freddy! I bet you like sittin' between two men in a dual wheel truck don't you?
answer: Oh, yeah, I'm thrilled.

question: I thought I told you to keep out!
answer: Leave.

question: Don't tell me what to do.
answer: Leave.

question: Don't tell me what to do.
answer: Leave.

question: Don't tell me what to do.
answer: Leave.

question: What are you doin' up again, Frank? You need to get a little sleep.
answer: Did Vaughan go home?

question: Yeah, he has to go to work in a little while. I do too.
answer: Did Karl go to bed?

question: I guess. He went to the garage. Poor thing, he's probably never seen such a crazy mess. He probably wants to go back and live in Mr. Cox's shop.
answer: I bet he don't. Karl likes me.

question: I know he does.
answer: Mama?

question: Huh?
answer: Is everything gonna be all right someday? I just stay nervous all the time just about.

question: Yeah, honey, someday everything's gonna be all right.
answer: Doyle wouldn't really kill you, would he?

question: I promise we're gonna get away from him. The time has to be right, that's all. I'd rather him get tired of me and leave me. Then he wouldn't want to hurt me. He wouldn't care then. We'll be fine. I promise. You go to bed now. I love you.
answer: I love you, too, Mama.

question: You scared me.
answer: I didn't aim to.

question: Want to sit down? Did you need somethin'?
answer: No ma'am. Two fellers was on a bridge a takin' a leak and one feller says the water was cold and the other said it was deep water. One of 'em came from Arkansas, I believe.

question: I'll be dog.
answer: Do you reckon you can make me some biscuits?

question: Right now?
answer: Just whenever you take a notion to. I don't aim to put you out.

question: Well, it is nearly breakfast time anyway. I can't go to sleep. I have to be at work in three hours. You know how it is when you just sleep an hour or two, you feel worse than if you hadn't slept at all?
answer: Yes ma'am.

question: Well, set down and I'll make some biscuits and gravy.
answer: Mustard's good on 'em to me.

question: Okay.
answer: Thank ye.

question: It's all right. You know I was thinkin' there's this girl that works with me. She's real heavy, but she's cute in the face. Well, you know, she's slow. She's a little bit, I think. She's not retarded, just -- it don't matter, listen to me. I thought you might like to meet her. Vaughan wants to have a little supper over at his house and we could invite her. Would you like that?
answer: I wouldn't mind a havin' supper.

question: Vaughan's "friend" will be there, too. He works at the funeral home. And Frank. You know Frank likes you a lot. He says you make him feel calm.
answer: I like Frank. He's a good boy. Me and him's made friends. Hit ain't right for me to keep from tellin' you how come me to be put in the state hospital.

question: That's okay. It's not really my business. I have wondered though. Why was it? Was it like a nervous breakdown?
answer: I killed my mother and a old boy name Jesse Dixon. I thought they was a-doin' wrong. I was about your boy's age. They say I'm well now from it.

question: Was that you? I remember that. I was only three or four, but I always heard about it growin' up. They say you're well?
answer: Yes ma'am. I like your garage. I wouldn't never hurt you or your boy. I'd lay my hand on the Bible and say the same thing.

question: How 'bout you, Jerry.
answer: How are you, Bill?

question: Doin' pretty good. Got a sick tiller here. What's got you down this way?
answer: Just thought I'd check on Karl and see if everything's working out.

question: Well, he's pretty quiet. Except for them rackets and breathin' things he does. Ain't threatened me with a killin' or anything. But boy you couldn't of been more right about him fixin' things. That son of a bitch is a regular Eli Whitney on a lawnmower. Loves french fries. Eats four larges and don't even so much as belch. I'm proud to have him.
answer: Is him stayin' here workin' out?

question: He's gone to stayin' over with that Wheatley boy and his mama in their garage. I think that little boy adopted him damn near like a mascot. But he's got a key here to come and go as he pleases. Everything's worked out good.
answer: Can I see him?

question: Sure. Scooter! Run get Karl for me.
answer: Are you sure you're okay staying with that woman and boy?

question: Are you sure you're okay staying with that woman and boy?
answer: Yes sir.

question: Do they know about you?
answer: My history.

question: Yeah.
answer: I told 'em about it. They know I'm well. That Mizz Wheatley made me some biscuits.

question: I'll be.
answer: That boy, he's my friend. He likes the way I talk and I like the way he talks.

question: Also, Melinda, please don't tell anybody at the store that Albert was here tonight, okay.
answer: Why?

question: Well, a lot of people in town talk and spread cruel rumors. Unfortunately, I have to keep certain parts of my life private.
answer: You mean about y'all bein' together in "that" way?

question: Yes.
answer: I think everybody at the store knows that already. They always talk about it. Maureen Ledbetter told a awful story about why you ain't allowed over at the First Baptist Church no more.

question: All right then.
answer: You walk fast, don't you?

question: I reckon.
answer: These is the worst shoes I own for walkin'. How far did you want to go?

question: Well, I just thought I'd give you them. I liked walkin' with you. I got a blister the size of a quarter on one heel. Well, I'll see you sometime, I guess.
answer: A blister shore can hurt.

question: Yeah.
answer: Flowers is pretty. I've always thought that.

question: Hey Karl, you off work?
answer: Yeah.

question: Where'd you get them flowers?
answer: That gal that made employee of the month give 'em to me for awalkin' with her.

question: I was goin' to the secret place. I borried one of your books to take down there. You ain't mad, are you?
answer: Naw. You can look at all my books you want to.

question: It's name's A Christmas Carol.
answer: That's than un on Christmas I was tellin' you about.

question: You want to go with me?
answer: Yeah.

question: I'm gettin' tired of readin' for a while.
answer: All right then.

question: Boy, folks sure had it rough back a long time ago, didn't they?
answer: Yeah, I reckon they did. Hit like to tore me up when I read about that pore little cripple boy.

question: Yeah, me too. That was nice of that woman to give you them flowers.
answer: Hit was right thoughty of her.

question: I was wantin' to ask you somethin'.
answer: All right then.

question: You know that girl I told you about. The one I love.
answer: Yeah, I recollect it.

question: Would you go see her with me? I kind of thought I might take her some flowers like that woman done you.
answer: If you want me to.

question: I ain't got no money to get 'em with but I bet Vaughan will let me have some of them flowers at the store.
answer: I bet he will. I got a little money if he don't. I'll get 'em for ye.

question: I usually get run off by her mama or daddy if they're home. Reckon why they don't like me?
answer: They ort to. You're a good boy.

question: Just 'cause I'm not rich don't mean I don't love her.
answer: Naw.

question: And I don't try to touch her. You know, in a bad way. Foolin' around, sex and all.
answer: That's real good. You ort not to if ye ain't married to somebody. Bible tells you that much. Hit tells some things that don't seem right too, I reckon. I guess a feller ort to foller it close as he can, though. You don't touch yourself, do you?

question: What do you mean?
answer: Pull on your works. Your privates.

question: Oh, jackin' off?
answer: Yes sir. You ort not know that language.

question: I didn't know till here while back a year or two ago when I spent the night with Ronnie Smart one time. He said just tug on your peter and think about your mama. I tried it, but I felt funny thinkin' about my mama. So, I switched over to thinkin' about his mama and then what he told me would happen, happened. It sure tingles, don't it?
answer: You ort not to pull on yourself that away.

question: I kind of like you tellin' me what to do and not to do. Just like my daddy. I didn't mind him tellin' me. I hate Doyle to tell me what to do. Mama said the only way to ever get away from him is for him to get away from us. That we can't leave him or he'll try and hurt her.
answer: He ain't no count.

question: You don't seem like a daddy. You seem like a brother. Wonder what makes you like somebody right off when you don't even know 'em like what happened with me and you.
answer: I don't reckon I know.

question: And then some people you don't like right off. It's funny. You know why I want you to play ball with me?
answer: Naw.

question: 'Cause it's fun. It don't matter if you ain't no good. It takes your mind off of everything else while you're doin' it. When you run real fast tryin' to make a touchdown you don't think about anything else. I ain't no good, but my daddy always said he was proud of me when I threw a ball or ran with it. Did you have any brothers and sisters growin' up to play with?
answer: I had one there for little bit. Hit didn't get old enough to play with.

question: Why not? It died?
answer: Yeah.

question: Why?
answer: Hit was borned a little too early on. My mother and father made hit come too early some way or other. I reckon they changed their mind about havin' another'n. I was about six or eight year old then and they didn't care too much for me so I reckon they didn't need somethin' else to worry 'em with.

question: So it died when it come out?
answer: My daddy come to the shed out back and got me and said throw this here away and handed me a towel with somethin' in it. I went for the trash barrel there and opened up the towel to see 'cause they was a noise and somethin' movin' in it. Hit was bloody-like around that towel. Hit was a little ol' bitty baby, no bigger than a squirrel.

question: It was alive?
answer: Yes sir. Right then it was.

question: A boy or girl?
answer: A little ol' boy.

question: You threw it in a trash barrel?
answer: I didn't feel right about doin' that. I takened a shoe box from there in the shed and emptied out some screwdrivers and nuts and warshers from it and put the little feller in that and buried him in the corner of the yard there. That seemed more proper to me, I reckon.

question: It was still alive when you buried it?
answer: I heared it cryin' a little through that box.

question: That don't seem right. It seems like you should have kept him alive and took care of him if he was your brother.
answer: I wadn't but six or eight. I reckon I didn't know what to do. I didn't know how to care for no baby. Mama and Daddy didn't want him. They learned me to do what they told me to. These days I figure it might of been best to give him right back to the Good Lord right off the bat anyhow.

question: That makes me feel real sad. Couldn't you have done somethin', Karl? I would have. I wish I would of had him. He'd be here right now. Livin'.
answer: Hits been hard thinkin' about it. They ain't a day goes by I don't think about it. I kindly have a picture of it up in my head that I see. Hit makes me sad, too. I have bad thoughts on it. I wished they was somethin' I could of did, too. Shouldn't no bad things happen to childern. All the ol' bad things ort to be saved up for folks that's growed up, the way I see it. I shouldn't of told you about that. A boy ort not hear about such things. It just kindly come out.

question: I didn't mean to say anything bad about you. I know you're good. You didn't mean no harm. Did you ever think about killin' yourself on purpose like my daddy did?
answer: I've studied about it. The Bible says not to or you end up goin' to Hades. Some folks calls it Hell, I call it Hades.

question: Bible says the same thing about killin' others, too.
answer: Yes sir, I reckon it does.

question: I always get nervous when I hear that doorbell. I'm okay just walkin' over, but somethin' about that dang doorbell. They have one room where you can't walk on the carpet or sit on the furniture. I don't see much sense in havin' it. Ma'am, I really want to give them to Karen.
answer: No ma'am.

question: Will you get her for me. Please. I really want to see her. She'll want to see me, too, 'cause we're not in public. Just don't tell her folks I'm here.
answer: Hey Frank. You shouldn't be coming over here. My parents really don't want you to.

question: I wanted to bring you some flowers. They're pretty good ones.
answer: They're from the Dollar Store. I'm not an idiot. Besides we have a garden full of flowers.

question: I wanted for you to meet Karl, too. He's my new friend. But I feel like I've always known him. I thought you should meet him.
answer: Why? Hi, Karl.

question: He's gonna be around a lot and I hope you are too, so...
answer: Here give me the flowers, I'll do something with them. Thank you. Now you better go. Maybe I'll see you down at the secret place one day in a week or two or something. I have a boyfriend now you know. And we're pretty serious. He gave me a ring.

question: Can you go there with us now? Me and Karl. We could just hang out. Karl has some cool books.
answer: Frank, I just like you as a friend. Only at the secret place. Okay? I can't go there now. I'll see you later.

question: But maybe just for awhile --
answer: I'm closing the door now. I told you, I'll see you later.

question: Well, at least he's tryin'. But who knows for how long.
answer: He's lyin' Mama. He ain't gonna do better.

question: I know honey. Just remember what I said, we'll bide our time. You just steer clear of him as much as you can. Doyle's had a real hard life. It's just about run him crazy I think.
answer: We've had a real hard life, too, Mama.

question: What you readin'?
answer: Readin' on this book on how to work carpentry. I aim to learn how to build things out of wood one of these times. I've always been partial to wood buildin's and cabinets and whatnot. These drawin's they got here don't make no sense to me so far. You seem like yore tails a'draggin' a might. You got somethin' wrong with ye?

question: Seems like Doyle's wormed his way back in. Mama said he's stayin' over tonight and he's talkin' about movin' in for good. We ain't ever gonna be happy. We'll always be nervous, won't we Karl?
answer: I don't reckon I know. I ain't found no way yet and I'm three or four times as old as you. Might be that's just the way folks is.

question: I feel sad about Karen Cross, too. I just make like to myself she loves me. I know better, though. It just feels good to me when I imagine it.
answer: Make believin' always made me feel good too from time to time. Bill Cox is goin' to a funeral for a Mister Turner tomorrow and a closin' up shop early.

question: Is that right?
answer: I'll play ball with ye. I reckon if neither one of us is no count it won't make no difference.

question: You will? For sure?
answer: Yeah.

question: We'll be on teams, me and you?
answer: Yessir.

question: Way to go, Karl. We got a touchdown. That was a good lateral, man. That was just like the Wishbone.
answer: I dern near had me a touchdown till them boys got a-hold of me there so I figured I better give it off to you. I seen you over there follerin' me.

question: We're liable to win if we keep this up. For somebody like you, you sure run fast. Come on, let's kick off to 'em. I know you could of scored them three touchdowns by yourself instead of throwing 'em over to me.
answer: Them boys was tryin' to pull me down pretty hard.

question: You're strong though. You let me make them touchdowns so I'd feel good. My daddy used to do that kind of thing. It don't matter to me about us losin' does it to you?
answer: No sir.

question: It was fun, anyhow.
answer: I wadn't thinkin' about nothin' else just like you told me I'd do.

question: Can we play ever' Saturday?
answer: If I ain't too stove up. I ain't like you. I'm old and give out. I'm proud of ye. I'm ye boy. I'm ye oldest boy name Karl. They turned me aloose from the nervous hospital. Said I was well. I got hired to work for a Mr. Cox fixin' lawnmowers and whatnot. That grass out in the yard's all growed up. I figured I might cut it fer ye. I learned to read some. I've read on the Bible quite a bit. I don't understand all of it, but I believe I understand a good deal of it. Them stories Mama and you told me ain't in there. You ort not to of done that to ye boy. I've studied on killin' you. But I don't reckon they's no reason fer it if all you're gonna do is set there in that chair. You'll be dead soon enough I reckon and the world'll be shut of ye. You ort not to of killed my brother. He ort to have had a chance to grow up. Sometimes he would of had fun. Little feller.

question: Where are you goin', Karl? Didn't you want some chicken and things?
answer: No ma'am. I'm a'goin' off sommers.

question: Well, okay. I got you some.
answer: Frank, he went off, too. He ain't gonna be in there when you get indoors.

question: Where'd he go? What's goin' on?
answer: He wanted to go off and play, I reckon. You go in there and you and that Doyle eat ye dinner. You don't have to worry yourself none.

question: All right then. Well, I'll see you later. If you see Frank, tell him to come on back home. I don't get to see him all day except Sundays. He can play tomorrow.
answer: Ma'am?

question: Yeah.
answer: You're a good mama to that boy. You care for him. You work hard fer him to take care of him. You light him up in his eyes, I've seen it. He wouldn't know what to do without ye.

question: Well thank you, hun. That's real good of you to say. I wouldn't know what to do without him either.
answer: You've been real good to me, too. It ain't ever'body that'd make biscuits in the middle of the night. You and that boy has give me a good feelin'.

question: We sure like havin' you.
answer: Thank ye. I'm just getting around to tellin' you, but I fixed your warshin' machine.

question: Thank ye. I'm just getting around to tellin' you, but I fixed your warshin' machine.
answer: Hey, Karl. How'd you know to come out here?

question: I knowed you'd be here. What are you a-doin' digging with that stob?
answer: Just diggin'. I ain't ever gonna be happy now. Not with that son of a bitch movin' in for good. I wish me and you and Mama could just run away. But she said he would find us wherever we went. He's crazy. Sometimes I think it would of been better if I wadn't ever born.

question: I'm glad of it you was borned. I reckon I ain't gonna be there in the garage no more.
answer: You have to Karl. You have to look out for me. You don't let that son of a bitch run you off.

question: You're just a boy. You ort not to use that sort of language.
answer: Karl, I ain't tryin' to say nothin' bad about you, but why don't you stop Doyle when he gets that away? You're older than him. You're strong, too. My daddy wouldn't let him do that to me and Mama.

question: That feller's a whole sight meaner than me. He'd just whup the tar out of me.
answer: Yeah, I guess so. I'm real tired, you know that. A kid my age shouldn't be tired of things.

question: I'm tired, too, Frank. If I ain't around no more, it don't mean I don't care fer ye. I care for ye a good deal. I care for you more than anybody they is. We made friends right off the bat.
answer: I care for you, too. But you'll be around, don't say that.

question: Hit don't make no difference where I was to be. We'll always be friends. There ain't no way to stop that. I aim for you to have these books. Maybe you can make more sense out of them than I can. I made you a little old book marker and stuck it in that book on Christmas.
answer: You don't want to give away all your books.

question: I aim fer you to have 'em.
answer: Man. Thanks. You know when you get a feelin' and you don't know why?

question: Yes sir.
answer: I've got a feelin' today.

question: Reckon what kind of a feelin'?
answer: Like something different. I don't know. You're leavin' ain't you, Karl?

question: Will ye do somethin' for me if I ast you to?
answer: You know I would. Whatever you want.

question: Don't go home tonight and stay with that Doyle. He's got it in for ye tonight. I got me a feelin', too. Feels like to me you ort not be there in that house with him liquored up and mean. Ye mama neither. When you get up from here, I want you to go to that feller's house. Your mama's friend. I want you to give me your word on it.
answer: Okay. I give you my word. Is ever'thing gonna be okay? Are you all right?

question: Ever'thing's okay, boy. I kindly want to put my arm around ye for a minute and then I'm gonna go on and leave here.
answer: Okay. Karl!

question: Karl, what are you doing here? Come in.
answer: I ain't a-stayin'. I need to ast you fer a favor.

question: Okay.
answer: This evenin' I want you to go get Mizz Wheatley and that Frank and have them stay with you tonight.

question: What's wrong? Is everything okay?
answer: That dern Doyle is in a bad way again with that drinkin' and bein' mean to folks. Will you give me your word you'll do it?

question: Well, sure, okay. He hasn't hurt them, has he?
answer: Naw, not yet. I want ye to give this to Mizz Wheatley. Hit ain't much, but maybe there's a little somethin' to hep out. Hits what I've earned fixin' lawnmowers and whatnot fer Bill Cox.

question: What about you, Karl? Do you want to stay here?
answer: I don't reckon you have to go with women to be a daddy to a boy. You've been real square dealin' with me. The Bible says two men ort not lay together. But I'll bet you the Good Lord wouldn't send nobody like you to Hades. Some folks calls it Hell, I call it Hades. That boy lives inside of his own heart. Hits an awful big place. You take care of that boy.

question: I don't reckon you have to go with women to be a daddy to a boy. You've been real square dealin' with me. The Bible says two men ort not lay together. But I'll bet you the Good Lord wouldn't send nobody like you to Hades. Some folks calls it Hell, I call it Hades. That boy lives inside of his own heart. Hits an awful big place. You take care of that boy.
answer: Where's ever'body else? You seen 'em? I thought I told you to get the hell moved out of here anyway.

question: How does a feller go about gettin' ahold of the police?
answer: Pick up the fuckin' phone and call 'em, I guess.

question: What numbers do you punch?
answer: I told you to get away from here, didn't I? I'm tryin' to relax and look at TV. What are you doin' with that piece of iron? I swear to God you're the weirdest son of a bitch I ever heard of.

question: I aim to kill you with it.
answer: Yeah, okay. Well, to get the police you push 911. You'll need to tell 'em to send an ambulance, too. Or a hearse. You fuckin' idiot. You're gonna kill me. Oh God! Oh God!
